internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

sectionBreak.stem:
The given figure shows a cylindrical tank with a conical base. If the liquid level is quite low, in the conical part, the volume is simply the conical volume of liquid. If the liquid level is midrange in the cylindrical part, the total volume of liquid includes the filled conical part and the partially filled cylindrical part.

 

%media:3-1.png%

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

doc.stem:
Use decisional structures to write an M-file to compute the tank’s volume as a function of given values of R and d. Design the function so that it returns the volume for all cases where the depth is less than 3R. Return an error message (“Overtop”) if you overtop the tank—that is, d > 3R. 

 

(Please upload your response/solution using the controls below.)
doc.info: question data is all stored in questionProperties...

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:
R d Volume of the cylindrical tank
[A(1)] 1 [A(2)]
[B(1)] 1.25 [B(2)]
[C(1)] 3.8 [C(2)]
1.3 [D(1)] [D(2)]

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What are the arguments required to write a function to calculate volume?

worksheet.stem:
Using M-file, find the volume of a cylindrical tank for the following data.

 

R [A(1)] [B(1)] [C(1)] 1.3
d 1 1.25 3.8 [D(1)]

Note that the tank's radius is R. (Round the final answers to four decimal places.)

 

R d Volume of the cylindrical tank
[A(1)] 1 __ANS1__
[B(1)] 1.25 __ANS2__
[C(1)] 3.8 __ANS3__
1.3 [D(1)] __ANS4__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The M-file can be written as

 

function Vol = tankvolume(R, d)
if d < R
  Vol = pi * d ^ 3 / 3;
elseif d <= 3 * R
  V1 = pi * R ^ 3 / 3;
  V2 = pi * R ^ 2 * (d - R);
  Vol = V1 + V2;
else
  Vol = 'overtop';
end

 

This function can be used to evaluate the given data.

 

>> tankvolume([A(1)],1)
ans =
   [A(2)]
>> tankvolume([B(1)],1.25)
ans =
   [B(2)]
>> tankvolume([C(1)],3.8)
ans =
   [C(2)]
>> tankvolume(1.3,[D(1)])
ans =
   [D(2)]

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

sectionBreak.stem:
An amount of money P is invested in an account where interest is compounded at the end of the period. The future worth F yielded at an interest rate i after n periods may be determined from the following formula:

 

           F = P(1 + i)n

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

doc.stem:
Write an M-file that will calculate the future worth of an investment for each year from 1 through n. The input to the function should include the initial investment P, the interest rate i (as a decimal), and the number of years n for which the future worth is to be calculated. The output should consist of a table with headings and columns for n and F.

 

(Please upload your response/solution using the controls below.)
doc.info: question data is all stored in questionProperties...

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:
Year Future worth
0 100000.00
1 105000.00
2 110250.00
3 115762.50
4 121550.63
5 127628.16
6 134009.56
7 140710.04
8 147745.54
9 155132.82
10 162889.46

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What are the arguments required to write a function to calculate the future worth?

worksheet.stem:
Using the M-file find the compound interest for P = $100,000, i = 0.05, and n = 10 years. (Round the final answer to two decimal places.)

 

Year Future worth
0 100000.00
1 105000.00
2 __ANS1__
3 115762.50
4 __ANS2__
5 __ANS3__
6 __ANS4__
7 __ANS5__
8 147745.54
9 __ANS6__
10 __ANS7__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The M-file can be written as


function futureworth(P, i, n)
nn=0:n;
F=P*(1+i).^nn;
y=[nn;F];
fprintf('\n year future worth\n');
fprintf('%5d %14.2f\n',y);


This function can be used to evaluate the test case.


>> futureworth(100000,0.05,10)
  year    future worth
    0     100000.00
    1     105000.00
    2     110250.00
    3     115762.50
    4     121550.63
    5     127628.16
    6     134009.56
    7     140710.04
    8     147745.54
    9     155132.82
   10     162889.46

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

sectionBreak.stem:
Economic formulas are available to compute annual payments for loans. Suppose that you borrow an amount of money P and agree to repay it in n annual payments at an interest rate of i. The formula to compute the annual payment A is

 

       %media:formula1.mml%

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

doc.stem:
Write an M-file to compute A. Compute results for n = 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 and display the results as a table with headings and columns for n and A.

 

(Please upload your response/solution using the controls below.)
doc.info: question data is all stored in questionProperties...

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:
Year Annual payment
1 103300.00
2 52488.39
3 35557.14
4 27095.97
5 22022.84

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What are the arguments required to write a function to compute annual payments for loans?

worksheet.stem:
Using M-file, find the value of annual payment (A) for P = $100,000 and an interest rate of 3.3% (i = 0.033). (Round the final answer to two decimal places.)

 

Year Annual payment
1 __ANS1__
2 __ANS2__
3 __ANS3__
4 __ANS4__
5 __ANS5__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The M-file can be written as


function annualpayment(P, i, n)
nn = 1:n;
A = P*i*(1+i).^nn./((1+i).^nn-1);
y = [nn;A];
fprintf('\n year annual payment\n');
fprintf('%5d %14.2f\n',y);

 


This function can be used to evaluate the test case.


>> annualpayment(100000,.033,5)
   year   annual payment
    1       103300.00
    2        52488.39
    3        35557.14
    4        27095.97
    5        22022.84

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

sectionBreak.stem:
The average daily temperature for an area can be approximated by the following function:

 

T = Tmean + (Tpeak − Tmean) cos(ω(t − tpeak))

 

where Tmean = the average annual temperature, Tpeak = the peak temperature, ω = the frequency of the annual variation (= 2π/365), and tpeak = day of the peak temperature (∼= 205 d). Parameters for some U.S. towns are listed here:

 

City Tmean (°C) Tpeak (°C)
Miami, FL 22.1 28.3
Yuma, AZ [A(1)] 33.6
Bismarck,ND 5.2 22.1
Seattle, WA [B(1)] 17.6
Boston, MA 10.7 22.9

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

doc.stem:
Develop an M-file that computes the average temperature between two days of the year for a particular city.

 

(Please upload your response/solution using the controls below.)
doc.info: question data is all stored in questionProperties...

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value: The average temperature for January–February in Yuma is [A(2)] °C.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What are the arguments required to write a function to find the average temperature?

worksheet.stem:
Find the average temperature for January–February in Yuma, AZ (t = 0 to 59) using the M-file. (Round the final answer to four decimal places.)

 

 

The average temperature for January–February in Yuma is __ANS__ °C.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The M-file can be written as follows:


function Ta = avgtemp(Tm, Tp, ts, te)
w = 2*pi/365;
t = ts:te;
T = Tm + (Tp-Tm)*cos(w*(t-205));
Ta = mean(T);

 

This function can be used to evaluate the test cases:

>> avgtemp([A(1)],33.6,0,59)
ans =
   [A(2)]

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

Find the average temperature for July–August in Seattle, WA (t = 180 to 242) using the M-file. (Round the final answer to four decimal places.)

 

 

The average temperature for for July–August in Seattle is __ANS__ °C.

function Ta = avgtemp(Tm, Tp, ts, te)
w = 2*pi/365;
t = ts:te;
T = Tm + (Tp-Tm)*cos(w*(t-205));
Ta = mean(T);

 

This function can be used to evaluate the average temperature:


>> avgtemp([B(1)],17.6,180,242)
ans =

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

sectionBreak.stem:
The sine function can be evaluated by the following infinite series:

 

%media:formula2.mml%

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

doc.stem:
Create an M-file to implement this formula so that it computes and displays the values of sin x as each term in the series is added. In other words, compute and display in sequence the values for

 

%media:formula3.mml%

 

%media:formula4.mml%

 

%media:formula5.mml%

         %media:formula6.mml%

 

up to the order term of your choosing. For each of the preceding, compute and display the percent relative error as

 

%media:formula7.mml%

 

(Please upload your response/solution using the controls below.)
doc.info: question data is all stored in questionProperties...

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:
Order True value Approximation Error
1 0.7833269096 0.9000000000 –14.89455921
2 0.7833269096 0.7785000000 0.61620628
3 0.7833269096 0.7834207500 –0.01197972
4 0.7833269096 0.7833258498 0.00013530
5 0.7833269096 0.7833269174 –0.00000100

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What are the arguments required to write a function that computes and displays the values of sin x?

worksheet.stem:
Using the M-file, compute sin(0.9) for up to and including five terms—that is, up to term x9/9!. (Round the final answers to seven decimal places.)

 

Order True value Approximation Error
1 0.7833269096 0.9000000000 __ANS1__
2 0.7833269096 __ANS2__ 0.61620628
3 0.7833269096 0.7834207500 __ANS3__
4 0.7833269096 __ANS4__ 0.00013530
5 0.7833269096 0.7833269174 –0.00000100
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The M-file can be written as follows:


function sincomp(x,n)
i = 1;
tru = sin(x);
ser = 0;
fprintf('\n');
fprintf('order true value approximation error\n');
while (1)
   if i > n, break, end
   ser = ser + (-1)^(i - 1) * x^(2*i-1) / factorial(2*i-1);
   er = (tru - ser) / tru * 100;
   fprintf('%3d %14.10f %14.10f %12.7f\n',i,tru,ser,er);
   i = i + 1;
end

 

This function can be used to evaluate the given function:


>> sincomp(0.9,5)
order   true value   approximation      error
  1   0.7833269096   0.9000000000   -14.89455921
  2   0.7833269096   0.7785000000     0.61620628
  3   0.7833269096   0.7834207500    -0.01197972
  4   0.7833269096   0.7833258498     0.00013530
  5   0.7833269096   0.7833269174    -0.00000100

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

sectionBreak.stem:
Two distances are required to specify the location of a point relative to an origin in two-dimensional space (see figure):

  • The horizontal and vertical distances (x, y) in Cartesian coordinates.
  • The radius and angle (r, θ) in polar coordinates.

It is relatively straightforward to compute Cartesian coordinates (x, y) on the basis of polar coordinates (r, θ). The reverse process is not so simple. The radius can be computed by the following formula:

 

%media:formula8.mml%

 

If the coordinates lie within the first and fourth coordinates (i.e., x > 0), then a simple formula can be used to compute θ:

 

%media:formula9.mml%

 

%media:3-6.png%

 

The difficulty arises for the other cases. The following table summarizes the possibilities:

 

x y θ
<0 >0 tan−1(y/x) + π
<0 <0 tan−1(y/x) − π
<0 =0 π
=0 >0 π/2
=0 <0 −π/2
=0 =0 0

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

doc.stem:
Write a well-structured M-file using if...elseif structures to calculate r and θ as a function of x and y. Express the final results for θ in degrees.

 

(Please upload your response/solution using the controls below.)
doc.info: question data is all stored in questionProperties...

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:
The required values are tabulated as follows:

 

x y r θ
2 0 2.000000 0
2 1 2.236068 26.565050
0 3 3.000000 90.000000
−3 1 3.162278 161.565100
−2 0 2.000000 180.000000
−1 −2 2.236068 –116.565000
0 0 0 0
0 −2 2.000000 –90.000000
2 2 2.828427 45.000000

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What is the value of θ when x > 0 and y < 0?

worksheet.stem:
Using M-file, evaluate the following cases. (Round the final answer to six decimal places.)

 

x y r θ
2 0 2.000000 0
2 1 __ANS1__ __ANS2__
0 3 __ANS3__ __ANS4__
−3 1 3.162278 161.565100
−2 0 __ANS5__ __ANS6__
−1 −2 __ANS7__ __ANS8__
0 0 0 0
0 −2 2.000000 –90.000000
2 2 2.828427 45.000000
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The M-file can be written as


function [r, th] = polar(x, y)
r = sqrt(x .^ 2 + y .^ 2);
if x > 0
  th = atan(y/x);
elseif x < 0
  if y > 0
    th = atan(y / x) + pi;
  elseif y < 0
    th = atan(y / x) - pi;
  else
    th = pi;
  end
else
  if y > 0
    th = pi / 2;
  elseif y < 0
    th = -pi / 2;
  else
    th = 0;
  end
end
th = th * 180 / pi;

 

 

This function can be used to evaluate the test cases. For example, for the first case,


>> [r,th]=polar(2,0)
r =
    2
th =
    0

 

All the cases are summarized as follows:

 

x y r θ
2 0 2.000000 0
2 1 2.236068 26.565050
0 3 3.000000 90.000000
−3 1 3.162278 161.565100
−2 0 2.000000 180.000000
−1 −2 2.236068 –116.565000
0 0 0 0
0 −2 2.000000 –90.000000
2 2 2.828427 45.000000

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

sectionBreak.stem:
Two distances are required to specify the location of a point relative to an origin in two-dimensional space (see figure):

  • The horizontal and vertical distances (x, y) in Cartesian coordinates.
  • The radius and angle (r, θ) in polar coordinates.

It is relatively straightforward to compute Cartesian coordinates (x, y) on the basis of polar coordinates (r, θ). The reverse process is not so simple. The radius can be computed by the following formula:

 

%media:formula8.mml%

 

If the coordinates lie within the first and fourth coordinates (i.e., x > 0), then a simple formula can be used to compute θ:

 

%media:formula9.mml%

 

%media:3-6.png%

 

The difficulty arises for the other cases. The following table summarizes the possibilities:

 

x y θ
<0 >0 tan−1(y/x) + π
<0 <0 tan−1(y/x) − π
<0 =0 π
=0 >0 π/2
=0 <0 −π/2
=0 =0 0

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

doc.stem:
Develop an M-file to determine polar coordinates. Design the function to evaluate the vectors of x and y. Have the function display the results as a table with columns for x, y, r, and θ.

 

(Please upload your response/solution using the controls below.)
doc.info: question data is all stored in questionProperties...

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:
The required values are tabulated as follows:

 

x y r θ
2 0 2.0000 0.0000
2 1 2.2361 26.5651
0 3 3.0000 90.0000
−3 1 3.1623 161.5651
−2 0 2.0000 180.0000
−1 −2 2.2361 –116.5651
0 0 0 0
0 −2 2.0000 –90.0000
2 2 2.8284 45.0000

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What is the value of θ when x > 0 and y < 0?

worksheet.stem:
Using M-file, evaluate the following cases. (Round the final answer to four decimal places.)

 

x y r θ
2 0 2.0000 0.0000
2 1 __ANS1__ __ANS2__
0 3 3.0000 90.0000
−3 1 __ANS3__ __ANS4__
−2 0 2.0000 180.0000
−1 −2 __ANS5__ __ANS6__
0 0 0 0
0 −2 2.0000 –90.0000
2 2 __ANS7__ __ANS8__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The M-file can be written as


function polar2(x, y)
r = sqrt(x .^ 2 + y .^ 2);
n = length(x);
for i = 1:n
   if x(i) > 0
     th(i) = atan(y(i) / x(i));
   elseif x(i) < 0
     if y(i) > 0
       th(i) = atan(y(i) / x(i)) + pi;
     elseif y(i) < 0
       th(i) = atan(y(i) / x(i)) - pi;
     else
       th(i) = pi;
     end
   else
     if y(i) > 0
       th(i) = pi / 2;
     elseif y(i) < 0
       th(i) = -pi / 2;
     else
       th(i) = 0;
     end
   end
   th(i) = th(i) * 180 / pi;
end
ou=[x;y;r;th];
fprintf('\n    x     y    radius    angle\n');
fprintf('%8.2f %8.2f %10.4f %10.4f\n',ou);

 


This function can be used to evaluate the test cases and display the results in tabular form.


>> x=[2 2 0 -3 -2 -1 0 0 2];
>> y=[0 1 3 1 0 -2 0 -2 2];
>> polar2(x,y)
   x      y     radius    angle
  2.00   0.00   2.0000    0.0000
  2.00   1.00   2.2361   26.5651
  0.00   3.00   3.0000   90.0000
 -3.00   1.00   3.1623  161.5651
 -2.00   0.00   2.0000  180.0000
 -1.00  -2.00   2.2361 -116.5651
  0.00   0.00   0.0000    0.0000
  0.00  -2.00   2.0000  -90.0000
  2.00   2.00   2.8284   45.0000

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

sectionBreak.stem:
Following is the scheme to assign letter grade to a numeric grade for students.

 

Letter Criteria
A 90 ≤ numeric grade ≤ 100
B 80 ≤ numeric grade < 90
C 70 ≤ numeric grade < 80
D 60 ≤ numeric grade < 70
F numeric grade < 60

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

doc.stem:
Develop an M-file function that is passed a numeric grade from 0 to 100 and returns a letter grade.

 

 

The first line of the function should be


function grade = lettergrade(score)

 

 

Design the function so that it displays an error message and terminates in the event that the user enters a value of score that is less than zero or greater than 100.

 

(Please upload your response/solution using the controls below.)
doc.info: question data is all stored in questionProperties...

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Which conditional statement can be used to find a letter grade from a numerical grade?

worksheet.stem:
Using M-file, identify the letter grade for the following numeric grades. 

 

Numeric grade Letter grade
[A(1)] __ANS1__
[B(1)] __ANS2__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The M-file can be written as


function grade = lettergrade(score)
if score <0 | score>100
error('Value must be >= 0 and <= 100')
elseif score >= 90
grade = 'A';
elseif score >= 80
grade = 'B';
elseif score >= 70
grade = 'C';
elseif score >= 60
grade = 'D';
else
grade = 'F';
end

 


This function can be tested with a few cases.


>> grade = lettergrade([A(1)])
grade =
  [A(2)]
>> grade = lettergrade([B(1)])
grade =
  [B(2)]

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

sectionBreak.stem:
Manning’s equation can be used to compute the velocity of water in a rectangular open channel:

 

%media:formula10.mml%

 

where U = velocity (m/s), S = channel slope, n = roughness coefficient, B = width (m), and H = depth (m). The following data are available for five channels:

 

n S B H
0.036 0.0001 10 2
0.020 0.0002 8 1
0.015 0.0012 20 1.5
0.030 0.0007 25 3
0.022 0.0003 15 2.6

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

doc.stem:
Write an M-file that computes the velocity for each of these channels. Enter these values into a matrix where each column represents a parameter and each row represents a channel. Have the M-file display the input data along with the computed velocity in tabular form where velocity is the fifth column. Include headings on the table to label the
columns.

 

(Please upload your response/solution using the controls below.)
doc.info: question data is all stored in questionProperties...

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:
The required values are tabulated as follows:

 

n S B H U
0.036 0.0001 10 2 0.3523
0.020 0.0002 8 1 0.6094
0.015 0.0012 20 1.5 2.7569
0.030 0.0007 25 3 1.5894
0.022 0.0003 15 2.6 1.2207

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Can the given Manning's equation be used to calculate the velocity?

worksheet.stem:
Using M-file, find the velocity for all five channels. (Round the final answers to four decimal places.)

 

n S B H U
0.036 0.0001 10 2 __ANS1__
0.020 0.0002 8 1 __ANS2__
0.015 0.0012 20 1.5 __ANS3__
0.030 0.0007 25 3 __ANS4__
0.022 0.0003 15 2.6 __ANS5__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The M-file can be written as follows:


function Manning(A)
A(:,5)=sqrt(A(:,2))./A(:,1).*(A(:,3).*A(:,4)./(A(:,3)+2*A(:,4))).^(2/3);
fprintf('\n  n    S     B     H     U\n');
fprintf('%8.3f %8.4f %10.2f %10.2f %10.4f\n',A');

 


This function can be run to create the table.

 
>> A=[.036 .0001 10 2
.020 .0002 8 1
.015 .0012 20 1.5
.03 .0007 25 3
.022 .0003 15 2.6];
>> Manning(A)
   n        S         B      H     U
  0.036   0.0001   10.00   2.00   0.3523
  0.020   0.0002    8.00   1.00   0.6094
  0.015   0.0012   20.00   1.50   2.7569

property.name: commonFeedback
property.value:
A vectorized version can be written as


tt=tstart:(tend-tstart)/ni:tend
yy=12+6*cos(2*pi*tt/(tend-tstart))

 

 

Both generate the following values for t and y:


t =
  0 2.5000 5.0000 7.5000 10.0000 12.5000 15.0000 17.5000 20.0000
y =
  18.0000 16.2426 12.0000 7.7574 6.0000 7.7574 12.0000 16.2426 18.0000

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:
The vectorized version of the given code is as follows:

 

tt=tstart:(tend-tstart)/ni:tend
yy=12+6*cos(2*pi*tt/(tend-tstart))

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What is the syntax to find the interval using ni provided in the program?

multipleChoice.stem:
Identify the vectorized version of the following code:

 

tstart=0; tend=20; ni=8;
t(1)=tstart;
y(1)=12 + 6*cos(2*pi*t(1)/(tend-tstart));
for i=2:ni+1
t(i)=t(i-1)+(tend-tstart)/ni;
y(i)=12 + 6*cos(2*pi*t(i)/(tend-tstart));
end
multipleChoice.commonFeedback:
A vectorized version can be written as


tt=tstart:(tend-tstart)/ni:tend
yy=12+6*cos(2*pi*tt/(tend-tstart))

 

 

Both generate the following values for t and y:


t =
  0 2.5000 5.0000 7.5000 10.0000 12.5000 15.0000 17.5000 20.0000
y =
  18.0000 16.2426 12.0000 7.7574 6.0000 7.7574 12.0000 16.2426 18.0000

sectionBreak.stem:
The “divide and average” method, an old-time method for approximating the square root of any positive number a, can be formulated as

 

%media:formula14.mml%

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

doc.stem:
Write a well-structured M-file function based on the while...break loop structure to implement this algorithm. Use proper indentation so that the structure is clear. At each step estimate the error in your approximation as

 

%media:formula15.mml%


Repeat the loop until ε is less than or equal to a specified value. Design your program so that it returns both the result and the error. Make sure that it can evaluate the square root of numbers that are equal to and less than zero. For the latter case, display the result as an imaginary number. For example, the square root of −4 would return 2i.

 

(Please upload your response/solution using the controls below.)
doc.info: question data is all stored in questionProperties...

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:
The square root of a = 0 and ε = 1 × 10–4 is 0.

The square root of a = [A(1)] and ε = 1 × 10–4 is [A(2)].

The square root of a = [B(1)] and ε = 1 × 10–4 is 0 + [B(2)]i.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What are the arguments required for while loop?

worksheet.stem:
Using M-file, evaluate for the following data: a = 0, [A(1)], and [B(1)] for ε = 1 × 10–4. (Round the final answers to four decimal places.)

 

The square root of a = 0 and ε = 1 × 10–4 is __ANS1__ + __ANS2__i.

 

The square root of a = [A(1)] and ε = 1 × 10–4 is __ANS3__ + __ANS4__i.

 

The square root of a = [B(1)] and ε = 1 × 10–4 is __ANS5__ + __ANS6__i.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The MATLAB code to find the square root can be written as

function s=SquareRoot(a,eps)
ind=1;
if a ~= 0
if a < 0
a=-a;ind=j;
end
x = a / 2;
while(1)
y = (x + a / x) / 2;
e = abs((y - x) / y);
x = y;
if e < eps, break, end
end
s = x;
else
s = 0;
end
s=s*ind;

 


The function can be tested:


>> SquareRoot(0,1e-4)
ans =
  0
>> SquareRoot([A(1)],1e-4)
ans =
  [A(2)]
>> SquareRoot([B(1)],1e-4)
ans =
  0 + [B(2)]i

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

doc.info: question data is all stored in questionProperties...

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:
The required values are tabulated as follows:

 

Original number Rounded number
[A(1)] {{[A(2)]:0.00}}
[B(1)] {{[B(2)]:0.00}}
[C(1)] {{[C(2)]:0.00}}
[D(1)] {{[D(2)]:0.00}}

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What happens if the number is exactly halfway between two possible rounded values while using the rounder function?

worksheet.stem:
Using the M-file, round the following numbers to two decimal digits.

 

[A(1)] [B(1)] [C(1)] [D(1)]

 

 

The rounded numbers are as follows:

Original number Rounded number
[A(1)] __ANS1__
[B(1)] __ANS2__
[C(1)] __ANS3__
[D(1)] __ANS4__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
This following function employs the round to larger method. For this approach, if the number is exactly halfway between two possible rounded values, it is always rounded to the larger number.


function xr=rounder(x, n)
if n < 0,error('negative number of integers illegal'),end
xr=round(x*10^n)/10^n;

 


Here are the test cases:


>> rounder([A(1)],2)
ans =
  [A(2)]
>> rounder([B(1)],2)
ans =
  [B(2)]
>> rounder([C(1)],2)
ans =
  [C(2)]
>> rounder([D(1)],2)
ans =
  [D(2)]

sectionBreak.stem: Consider the elapsed days for a particular date.

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

doc.stem:
Develop an M-file function to determine the elapsed days in a year. The first line of the function should be set up as

 

function nd = days(mo, da, leap)


where mo = the month (1–12), da = the day (1–31), and leap = (0 for non–leap year and 1 for leap year).

 

(Please upload your response/solution using the controls below.)
doc.info: question data is all stored in questionProperties...

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:
The required values are tabulated as follows:

 

Date Number days elapsed
[A(1)] [A(3)], [A(4)] [A(6)]
[B(1)] [B(3)], [B(4)] [B(6)]

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: How can a month having 30 days be differentiated from a month having 31 or 28 days?

worksheet.stem:
Using M-file, determine the elapsed days in a year for the following dates:

 

Dates [A(1)] [A(3)], [A(4)] [B(1)] [B(3)], [B(4)]

 

The elapsed days for the given dates are as follows:

 

Date Number days elapsed
[A(1)] [A(3)], [A(4)] __ANS1__
[B(1)] [B(3)], [B(4)] __ANS2__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Following is the MATLAB function to find the elapsed days in a year.

 

function nd = days(mo, da, leap)
nd = 0;
for m=1:mo-1
switch m
case {1, 3, 5, 7, 8, 10, 12}
nday = 31;
case {4, 6, 9, 11}
nday = 30;
case 2
nday = 28+leap;
end
nd=nd+nday;
end
nd = nd + da;

 

 

Here are the test cases:

 

>> days([A(2)],[A(3)],[A(5)])
ans =
   [A(6)]
>> days([B(2)],[B(3)],[B(5)])
ans =
   [B(6)]

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

sectionBreak.stem: Consider the elapsed days for particular date.

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

doc.stem:
Develop an M-file function to determine the elapsed days in a year. The first line of the function should be set up as

 

function nd = days(mo, da, year)

 

where mo = the month (1–12), da = the day (1–31), and year = the year.

 

(Please upload your response/solution using the controls below.)
doc.info: question data is all stored in questionProperties...

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:
The required values are tabulated as follows:

 

Date Number days elapsed
[A(1)] [A(3)], [A(4)] {{[A(5)]:#.##}}
[B(1)] [B(3)], [B(4)] {{[B(5)]:#.##}}

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: How can a month with 31 days be differentiated from a month with 30 days?

worksheet.stem:
Using M-file, determine the elapsed days in a year for the following dates.

Dates [A(1)] [A(3)], [A(4)] [B(1)] [B(3)], [B(4)]

 

Date Number days elapsed
[A(1)] [A(3)], [A(4)] __ANS1__
[B(1)] [B(3)], [B(4)] __ANS2__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Following is the MATLAB function to find the elapsed days in a year.

 

function nd = days(mo, da, year)
leap = 0;
if year / 4 - fix(year / 4) == 0, leap = 1; end
nd = 0;
for m=1:mo-1
switch m
case {1, 3, 5, 7, 8, 10, 12}
nday = 31;
case {4, 6, 9, 11}
nday = 30;
case 2
nday = 28+leap;
end
nd=nd+nday;
end
nd = nd + da;

 

 

Here are the test cases:

 

>> days([A(2)],[A(3)],[A(4)])
ans =
    [A(5)]
>> days([B(2)],[B(3)],[B(4)])
ans =
    [B(5)]

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

sectionBreak.stem: It is possible to return the difference between the passed function's maximum and minimum value given a range of the independent variable.

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

doc.stem:
Develop an M-file function to return the difference between the passed function's maximum and minimum value given a range of the independent variable. In addition, have the function generate a plot of the function for the range.

 

(Please upload your response/solution using the controls below.)
doc.info: question data is all stored in questionProperties...

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value: The difference between the passed function’s maximum and minimum value for the given range is 10.7910.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What are the arguments required to write a function that returns the difference between the passed function’s maximum and minimum value given a range of the independent variable?

worksheet.stem:
Using the M-file, find the difference between the given passed function’s maximum and minimum value.

 

f(t) = 8e–0.25tsin(t – 2) from t = 0 to 6π.

 

(Round the final answer to four decimal places.)

 

The difference between the passed function’s maximum and minimum value for the given range is __ANS__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Following is the MATLAB function to find the difference between the passed function’s maximum and minimum value given a range of the independent variable.

 

function fr = funcrange(f,a,b,n,varargin)
% funcrange: function range and plot
% fr=funcrange(f,a,b,n,varargin): computes difference
% between maximum and minimum value of function over
% a range. In addition, generates a plot of the function.
% input:
% f = function to be evaluated
% a = lower bound of range
% b = upper bound of range
% n = number of intervals
% output:
% fr = maximum - minimum
x = linspace(a,b,n);
y = f(x,varargin{:});
fr = max(y)-min(y);
fplot(f,[a b],varargin{:})
end

 

 

Here is the MATLAB session for the given function.

 

>> f=@(t) 8*exp(-0.25*t).*sin(t-2);
>> funcrange(f,0,6*pi,1000)
ans =
  10.7910

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

function fr = funcrange(f,a,b,n,varargin)
% funcrange: function range and plot
% fr=funcrange(f,a,b,n,varargin): computes difference
% between maximum and minimum value of function over
% a range. In addition, generates a plot of the function.

The built-in humps function from x = 0 to 2.

worksheet.commonFeedback:
Following is the MATLAB function to find the difference between the passed function’s maximum and minimum value given a range of the independent variable.

 

function fr = funcrange(f,a,b,n,varargin)
% funcrange: function range and plot
% fr=funcrange(f,a,b,n,varargin): computes difference
% between maximum and minimum value of function over
% a range. In addition, generates a plot of the function.

y = f(x,varargin{:});
fr = max(y)-min(y);

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

sectionBreak.stem:
A MATLAB function odesimp is developed to solve the bungee jumper problem.

 

function yend = odesimp(dydt, dt, ti, tf, yi)
t = ti; y = yi; h = dt;
while (1)
if t + dt > tf, h = tf - t; end
y = y + dydt(y) * h;
t = t + h;
if t >= tf, break, end
end
yend = y;

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

doc.stem:
Modify the given odesimp function so that it can be passed the arguments of the passed function.

 

(Please upload your response/solution using the controls below.)
doc.info: question data is all stored in questionProperties...

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value: The output of the given case is [A(2)].

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Which argument has to be added to the modified odesimp function?

worksheet.stem:
Using the M-file, test the below case. (Round the final answer to four decimal places.)

 

>> dvdt=@(v,m,cd) 9.81-(cd/m)*v^2;
>> odesimp(dvdt,0.5,0,[A(1)],-10,70,0.23)

 

The output of the given case is __ANS__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Following is the modified odesimp function.

 

function yend = odesimp(dydt, dt, ti, tf, yi, varargin)
% odesimp: Euler ode solver
% yend = odesimp(dydt, dt, ti, tf, yi, varargin):
% Euler's method solution of a single ode
% input:
% dydt = function defining ode
% dt = time step
% ti = initial time
% tf = final time
% yi = initial value of dependent variable
% output:
% yend = dependent variable at final time
t = ti; y = yi; h = dt;
while (1)
if t + dt > tf, h = tf - t; end
y = y + dydt(y,varargin{:}) * h;
t = t + h;
if t >= tf, break, end
end
yend = y;

 

 

Here is the MATLAB session for the given case.

 

>> dvdt=@(v,m,cd) 9.81-(cd/m)*v^2;
>> odesimp(dvdt,0.5,0,[A(1)],-10,70,0.23)
ans =
  [A(2)]

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

sectionBreak.stem:
A Cartesian vector can be thought of as representing magnitudes along the x-, y-, and z-axes multiplied by a unit vector (i, j, k). For such cases, the dot product of two of these vectors {a} and {b} corresponds to the product of their magnitudes and the cosine of the angle between their tails as in


{a}·{b} = ab cosθ

 

The cross product yields another vector, {c} = {a} × {b}, which is perpendicular to the plane defined by {a} and {b} such that its direction is specified by the right-hand rule.

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

doc.stem:
Develop an M-file function that is passed two such vectors and returns θ, {c} and the magnitude of {c}, and generates a three-dimensional plot of the three vectors {a}, {b}, and {c} with their origins at zero. Use dashed lines for {a} and {b} and a solid line for {c}.

 

(Please upload your response/solution using the controls below.)
doc.info: question data is all stored in questionProperties...

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:
The value of θ is 38.2132.

The vector {c} is [ 4 –20 28].

The magnitude of {c} is 34.6410.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Is it possible to consider two vectors as arguments for the function?

worksheet.stem:
Using M-file, find the value of θ, {c}, and magnitude of {c} for two vectors {a} and {b}. 

>> a = [6 4 2]; b = [2 6 4];

 

The value of θ is __ANS1__. (Round the final answer to four decimal places.)

 

The vector {c} is [ __ANS2__    __ANS3__    __ANS4__ ]. (Round the final answers to the nearest integer.)

 

The magnitude of {c} is __ANS5__. (Round the final answer to four decimal places.)
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Following is the MATLAB function that returns θ, {c} and the magnitude of {c}, and generates a three-dimensional plot of the three vectors {a}, {b}, and {c} with their origins at zero.

 

function [theta,c,mag]=vector(a,b)
amag=norm(a);
bmag=norm(b);
adotb=dot(a,b);
theta=acos(adotb/amag/bmag)*180/pi;
c=cross(a,b);
mag=norm(c);
x1=[0 a(1)];y1=[0 a(2)];z1=[0 a(3)];
x2=[0 b(1)];y2=[0 b(2)];z2=[0 b(3)];
x3=[0 c(1)];y3=[0 c(2)];z3=[0 c(3)];
x4=[0 0];y4=[0 0];z4=[0 0];
plot3(x1,y1,z1,'--b',x2,y2,z2,'--r',x3,y3,z3,'-k',x4,y4,z4,'o')
xlabel='x';ylabel='y';zlabel='z';

 

 

Here is the MATLAB script for vectors {a} and {b}.

a = [6 4 2]; b = [2 6 4];
[th,c,m]=vector(a,b)
th =
  38.2132

doc.stem:

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:
The value of θ is 90.

The vector {c} is [ –16  –27  –17].

The magnitude of {c} is 35.6931.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Is it possible to consider two vectors as arguments for the function?

worksheet.stem:
Using the M-file, find the value of θ, {c}, and magnitude of {c} for two vectors a and b. 

>> a = [3 2 -6]; b = [4 -3 1];

 

The value of θ is __ANS1__. (Round the final answer to the nearest integer.)

 

The vector {c} is [ __ANS2__    __ANS3__    __ANS4__ ]. (Round the final answers to the nearest integer.)

 

The magnitude of {c} is __ANS5__. (Round the final answer to four decimal places.)
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Following is the MATLAB function that returns θ, {c} and the magnitude of {c}, and generates a three-dimensional plot of the three vectors {a}, {b}, and {c} with their origins at zero.

 

function [theta,c,mag]=vector(a,b)
amag=norm(a);
bmag=norm(b);
adotb=dot(a,b);
theta=acos(adotb/amag/bmag)*180/pi;
c=cross(a,b);
mag=norm(c);
x1=[0 a(1)];y1=[0 a(2)];z1=[0 a(3)];
x2=[0 b(1)];y2=[0 b(2)];z2=[0 b(3)];
x3=[0 c(1)];y3=[0 c(2)];z3=[0 c(3)];
x4=[0 0];y4=[0 0];z4=[0 0];
plot3(x1,y1,z1,'--b',x2,y2,z2,'--r',x3,y3,z3,'-k',x4,y4,z4,'o')
xlabel='x';ylabel='y';zlabel='z';

 

 

Here is the MATLAB script for vectors a and b.

a = [3 2 -6]; b = [4 -3 1];
[th,c,m]=vector(a,b)
th =
   90
c =
  -16   -27   -17
m =
   35.6931

worksheet.stem:
Using the M-file, find the value of θ, {c}, and magnitude of {c} for two vectors {a} and {b}. (Round the final answers to the nearest integer.)

>> a = [2 -2 1]; b = [4 2 -4];

 

The value of θ is __ANS1__.

 

The  vector {c} is [ __ANS2__    __ANS3__    __ANS4__ ].

 

The magnitude of {c} is __ANS5__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Following is the MATLAB function that returns θ, {c} and the magnitude of {c}, and generates a three-dimensional plot of the three vectors {a}, {b}, and {c} with their origins at zero.

 

function [theta,c,mag]=vector(a,b)
amag=norm(a);
bmag=norm(b);
adotb=dot(a,b);
theta=acos(adotb/amag/bmag)*180/pi;
c=cross(a,b);
mag=norm(c);
x1=[0 a(1)];y1=[0 a(2)];z1=[0 a(3)];
x2=[0 b(1)];y2=[0 b(2)];z2=[0 b(3)];
x3=[0 c(1)];y3=[0 c(2)];z3=[0 c(3)];
x4=[0 0];y4=[0 0];z4=[0 0];
plot3(x1,y1,z1,'--b',x2,y2,z2,'--r',x3,y3,z3,'-k',x4,y4,z4,'o')
xlabel='x';ylabel='y';zlabel='z';

 

 

Here is the MATLAB script for vectors {a} and {b}.

a = [2 -2 1]; b = [4 2 -4];
[th,c,m]=vector(a,b)
th =
   90
c =
   6   12   12
m =
   18

worksheet.stem:
Using the M-file, find the value of θ, {c}, and magnitude of {c} for two vectors {a} and {b}.  (Round the final answers to the nearest integer.)

>> a = [-1 0 0]; b = [0 -1 0];

 

The value of θ is __ANS1__. 

 

The vector {c} is [ __ANS2__    __ANS3__    __ANS4__ ]. 

 

The magnitude of {c} is __ANS5__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Following is the MATLAB function that returns θ, {c} and the magnitude of {c}, and generates a three-dimensional plot of the three vectors {a}, {b}, and {c} with their origins at zero.

 

function [theta,c,mag]=vector(a,b)
amag=norm(a);
bmag=norm(b);
adotb=dot(a,b);
theta=acos(adotb/amag/bmag)*180/pi;
c=cross(a,b);
mag=norm(c);
x1=[0 a(1)];y1=[0 a(2)];z1=[0 a(3)];
x2=[0 b(1)];y2=[0 b(2)];z2=[0 b(3)];
x3=[0 c(1)];y3=[0 c(2)];z3=[0 c(3)];
x4=[0 0];y4=[0 0];z4=[0 0];
plot3(x1,y1,z1,'--b',x2,y2,z2,'--r',x3,y3,z3,'-k',x4,y4,z4,'o')
xlabel='x';ylabel='y';zlabel='z';

 

 

Here is the MATLAB script for vectors {a} and {b}.

a = [-1 0 0]; b = [0 -1 0];
[th,c,m]=vector(a,b)
th =
  90
c =
  0   0   1
m =
  1

sectionBreak.stem:
In the absence of air resistance, the Cartesian coordinates of a projectile launched with an initial velocity (v0) and angle (θ0) can be computed with

 

x = v0 cos(θ0)t
y = v0 sin(θ0)t – 0.5gt2


where g = 9.81 m/s2.

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

doc.stem:
Develop a script to produce an animation of a bouncing ball where v0 =  5 m/s and θ0 = 50°. To do this, you must be able to predict exactly when the ball hits the ground. At this point, the direction changes (the new angle will equal the negative of the angle at impact), and the velocity will decrease in magnitude to reflect energy loss due to the collision of the ball with the ground. The change in velocity can be quantified by the coefficient of restitution CR which is equal to the ratio of the velocity after to the velocity before impact.

 

(Please upload your response/solution using the controls below.)
doc.info: question data is all stored in questionProperties...

sectionBreak.stem: A MATLAB function can be developed to produce an animation of a particle moving in a circle in Cartesian coordinates based on radial coordinates.

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

doc.stem:
Develop such a MATLAB function. Assume a constant radius, r, and allow the angle, θ, to increase from zero to 2π in equal increments.

 

The function's first lines should be

function phasor(r, nt, nm)
% function to show the orbit of a phasor
% r = radius
% nt = number of increments for theta
% nm = number of movies
